body:
one of the challenges of PATCH is idiomatically handling it.

the json-patch rfc is pretty good though sadly no gson impl exists for it.
 there's a jackson LGPL project though https://github.com/fge/json-patch

On Wed, Jul 24, 2013 at 10:33 AM, Marijn van der Werf <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> The PATCH method can be used to only edit some properties of a resource,
> instead of overwriting it as PUT does. Unfortunately, Retrofit doesn't
> offer support for PATCH requests. Are there any plans of adding this
> request method?
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/square/retrofit/issues/282
> .

I already tried that, by replicating the PUT annotation (with `@RestMethod(value = "PATCH", hasBody = true)`). Unfortunately this causes a `retrofit.RetrofitError`: `java.net.ProtocolException: Unknown method 'PATCH'; must be one of [OPTIONS, GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, TRACE]`.

Is there a way to add a `X-HTTP-Method-Override: PUT` only to specific interface methods?

As for a parseable response: I was planning to return a full object, but I understand that using a json-patch instead would possibly make things quite complicated.

That's a bug then! A custom annotation is the right way to do this. We can't feasibly support every HTTP method on the planet (since you can make arbitrary ones) and like @adriancole PATCH has certain semantics which we can't know.
Can you paste the full stack trace?

Will this suffice?

```
retrofit.RetrofitError: java.net.ProtocolException: Unknown method 'PATCH'; must be one of [OPTIONS, GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, TRACE]
    at retrofit.RestAdapter$RestHandler.invokeRequest(RestAdapter.java:292)
    at retrofit.RestAdapter$RestHandler.access$400(RestAdapter.java:157)
    at retrofit.RestAdapter$RestHandler$1.obtainResponse(RestAdapter.java:199)
    at retrofit.CallbackRunnable.run(CallbackRunnable.java:38)
    at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1080)
    at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:573)
    at retrofit.Platform$Android$2$1.run(Platform.java:132)
    at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:841)
Caused by: java.net.ProtocolException: Unknown method 'PATCH'; must be one of [OPTIONS, GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, TRACE]
    at java.net.HttpURLConnection.setRequestMethod(HttpURLConnection.java:677)
    at retrofit.client.UrlConnectionClient.prepareRequest(UrlConnectionClient.java:41)
    at retrofit.client.UrlConnectionClient.execute(UrlConnectionClient.java:32)
    at retrofit.RestAdapter$RestHandler.invokeRequest(RestAdapter.java:241)
    at retrofit.RestAdapter$RestHandler.access$400(RestAdapter.java:157)
    at retrofit.RestAdapter$RestHandler$1.obtainResponse(RestAdapter.java:199)
    at retrofit.CallbackRunnable.run(CallbackRunnable.java:38)
    at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1080)
    at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:573)
    at retrofit.Platform$Android$2$1.run(Platform.java:132)
    at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:841)
```
Yep. I just needed to see which client this was happening in so I can easily reproduce.
I am attempting to use @PATCH. The retrofit logs say "PATCH", but my server says it is receiving a POST. I have tried both OkClient and UrlConnectionClient.
@alecplumb can you use okhttp's MockWebServer to confirm this in a test case?

issue.title: Remove hack to support PATCH in HttpUrlConnection.

repository.name: retrofit
repository.description: A type-safe HTTP client for Android and the JVM

issue.title: Retrofit module: Unknown method 'PATCH'

repository.name: robospice
repository.description: Repo of the Open Source Android library : RoboSpice. RoboSpice is a modular android library that makes writing asynchronous long running tasks easy. It is specialized in network requests, supports caching and offers REST requests out-of-the box using extension modules.

issue.body:
Got this error with error with `com.octo.android.robospice:robospice-retrofit:1.4.12`. It is a bit confusing, cause this issue is already fixed in Retrofit library (https://github.com/square/retrofit/issues/282). Does anybody have idea how to fix this error?

I'm using Android studio. Libraries added to `build.gradle` as:

```
dependencies {
    compile 'com.octo.android.robospice:robospice-ormlite:1.4.12'
    compile 'com.octo.android.robospice:robospice-spring-android:1.4.12'
    compile 'com.fasterxml.jackson.core:jackson-databind:2.4.0-rc1'
    compile 'com.squareup.retrofit:converter-jackson:1.6.0'
    compile 'com.octo.android.robospice:robospice-retrofit:1.4.12'

    .....
}
```

Here is full exception:

```
06-23 13:59:53.932    2004-2025/com.myapp.sales E/ï¹• An exception occurred during request network execution :Unknown method 'PATCH'; must be one of [OPTIONS, GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, TRACE]
    retrofit.RetrofitError: Unknown method 'PATCH'; must be one of [OPTIONS, GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, TRACE]
            at retrofit.RestAdapter$RestHandler.invokeRequest(RestAdapter.java:389)
            at retrofit.RestAdapter$RestHandler.invoke(RestAdapter.java:240)
            at $Proxy1.updateUserInfo(Native Method)
            at com.myapp.sales.requests.PatchUserInfoRequest.loadDataFromNetwork(PatchUserInfoRequest.java:38)
            at com.myapp.sales.requests.PatchUserInfoRequest.loadDataFromNetwork(PatchUserInfoRequest.java:10)
            at com.octo.android.robospice.request.CachedSpiceRequest.loadDataFromNetwork(CachedSpiceRequest.java:45)
            at com.octo.android.robospice.request.DefaultRequestRunner.processRequest(DefaultRequestRunner.java:149)
            at com.octo.android.robospice.request.DefaultRequestRunner$1.run(DefaultRequestRunner.java:216)
            at java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:442)
            at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask$Sync.innerRun(FutureTask.java:305)
            at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:137)
            at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1076)
            at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:569)
            at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:856)
```

body:
I ran into this issue (v1.6.1) as well, was wondering if `PATCH` is supported. I am new to Android/Retrofit so not sure if this has been addressed.

```
D/Retrofitï¹• java.net.ProtocolException: Unknown method 'PATCH'; must be one of [OPTIONS, GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, TRACE]
            at java.net.HttpURLConnection.setRequestMethod(HttpURLConnection.java:677)
            at retrofit.client.UrlConnectionClient.prepareRequest(UrlConnectionClient.java:50)
            at retrofit.client.UrlConnectionClient.execute(UrlConnectionClient.java:37)
            at retrofit.RestAdapter$RestHandler.invokeRequest(RestAdapter.java:321)
            at retrofit.RestAdapter$RestHandler.access$100(RestAdapter.java:220)
            at retrofit.RestAdapter$RestHandler$2.obtainResponse(RestAdapter.java:278)
            at retrofit.CallbackRunnable.run(CallbackRunnable.java:42)
            at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1080)
            at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:573)
            at retrofit.Platform$Android$2$1.run(Platform.java:142)
            at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:841)
```

That's a limitation of the built-in HttpUrlConnection. You need to use
OkHttp or Apache HttpClient instead.
On Jul 20, 2014 2:49 PM, "Kapil" notifications@github.com wrote:

> I ran into this issue (v1.6.1) as well, was wondering if PATCH is
> supported. I am new to Android/Retrofit so not sure if this has been
> addressed.
>

>             at java.net.HttpURLConnection.setRequestMethod(HttpURLConnection.java:677)
>             at retrofit.client.UrlConnectionClient.prepareRequest(UrlConnectionClient.java:50)

Thanks. How can I get the latest `okhttp` build, I am getting this error -

I downloaded `v2.0.0` from here - http://square.github.io/okhttp/

```
E/AndroidRuntimeï¹• FATAL EXCEPTION: main
    java.lang.RuntimeException: Retrofit detected an unsupported OkHttp on the classpath.
    To use OkHttp with this version of Retrofit, you'll need:
    1. com.squareup.okhttp:okhttp:1.6.0 (or newer)
    2. com.squareup.okhttp:okhttp-urlconnection:1.6.0 (or newer)
    Note that OkHttp 2.0.0+ is supported!
            at retrofit.Platform.hasOkHttpOnClasspath(Platform.java:186)
```
You need both the okhttp jar and the okhttp-urlconnection jar. Downloads are here: http://search.maven.org/#search%7Cga%7C1%7Cg%3Acom.squareup.okhttp

Now I get this error -

```
Retrofitï¹• java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: com.squareup.okhttp.internal.http.RetryableSink
            at com.squareup.okhttp.internal.Util.<clinit>(Util.java:231)
            at com.squareup.okhttp.ConnectionPool.<init>(ConnectionPool.java:82)
            at com.squareup.okhttp.ConnectionPool.<clinit>(ConnectionPool.java:71)
            at com.squareup.okhttp.OkHttpClient.copyWithDefaults(OkHttpClient.java:477)
            at com.squareup.okhttp.OkUrlFactory.open(OkUrlFactory.java:66)
            at com.squareup.okhttp.OkUrlFactory.open(OkUrlFactory.java:61)
            at retrofit.client.OkClient.openConnection(OkClient.java:45)
            at retrofit.client.UrlConnectionClient.execute(UrlConnectionClient.java:36)
            at retrofit.RestAdapter$RestHandler.invokeRequest(RestAdapter.java:321)
            at retrofit.RestAdapter$RestHandler.access$100(RestAdapter.java:220)
            at retrofit.RestAdapter$RestHandler$2.obtainResponse(RestAdapter.java:278)
            at retrofit.CallbackRunnable.run(CallbackRunnable.java:42)
            at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1080)
            at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:573)
            at retrofit.Platform$Android$2$1.run(Platform.java:142)
            at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:841)
```

I am using Android Studio and have added both the jars to Gradle dependency -

```
dependencies {
   compile files('libs/retrofit-1.6.1.jar')
   compile files('libs/gson-2.2.4.jar')
   compile files('libs/okhttp-2.0.0.jar')
   compile files('libs/okhttp-urlconnection-2.0.0.jar')
}
```

If you are using Gradle you can stop ferrying jars around. Try:

``` groovy
dependencies {
  compile 'com.squareup.retrofit:retrofit:1.6.1'
  compile 'com.squareup.okhttp:okhttp:2.0.0'
  compile 'com.squareup.okhttp:okhttp-urlconnection:2.0.0'
}
```

Hey @kapso, do you mind to share how to get PATCH to work in Android Studio?  I am new to retrofit, so any help will be highly appreciated.

Thanks!

@pdichone You just need to add the gradle the following dependences:

```
compile 'com.squareup.retrofit:retrofit:1.9.0'
compile 'com.squareup.okhttp:okhttp:2.0.0'
compile 'com.squareup.okhttp:okhttp-urlconnection:2.0.0'
```

And the patch will start working.
